title: Moyamoya Disease
icd10: I63.50 (Cerebral infarction due to unspecified occlusion or stenosis of unspecified cerebral artery)
scope: ** Diagnosis and management of moyamoya disease and moyamoya syndrome in adults. Covers acute stroke management in moyamoya, diagnostic workup, medical management, surgical revascularization evaluation and options, and long-term monitoring. Distinguishes moyamoya disease (idiopathic, bilateral) from moyamoya syndrome (secondary to other conditions). Excludes pediatric moyamoya (different surgical considerations and natural history) and other causes of ischemic stroke covered in separate templates.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Polycythemia (compensatory in chronic ischemia); anemia (worsens ischemia); thrombocytosis (risk factor); baseline for surgery
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; polycythemia → chronic cerebral ischemia; anemia → optimize Hgb

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Electrolytes; glucose (hypo/hyperglycemia worsen ischemic injury); renal function (contrast planning); hepatic function
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; glucose 80-180 (avoid hypoglycemia); optimize metabolic parameters

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline coagulation; pre-surgical evaluation; hemorrhagic presentation; anticoagulation status
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; prolonged → evaluate cause before antiplatelet/surgical therapy

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Cardiovascular risk factor assessment; moyamoya syndrome workup (atherosclerotic component)
Diabetes assessment; glycemic control affects stroke risk and outcomes
Inflammatory markers; exclude vasculitis as cause of moyamoya syndrome; autoimmune conditions
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; elevated → consider vasculitis, autoimmune, or infectious etiology

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Thyroid disease associated with moyamoya syndrome (especially Graves disease); autoimmune thyroiditis
**CRITICAL**: Hypoglycemia worsens ischemic injury in moyamoya; hyperglycemia increases infarct volume
Preparation for potential surgical intervention; hemorrhagic presentation
Pregnancy increases stroke risk in moyamoya; alters surgical and medical management

Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Normal hemoglobin pattern; HbSS or HbSC → sickle cell-related moyamoya syndrome

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: SLE-associated moyamoya syndrome; autoimmune vasculopathy screening
Autoimmune thyroid disease (Graves, Hashimoto) associated with moyamoya
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Negative; positive → autoimmune thyroid-associated moyamoya syndrome

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Hyperhomocysteinemia as vascular risk factor; associated with moyamoya in some studies
Antiphospholipid syndrome can cause progressive intracranial stenosis mimicking moyamoya
Low complement in active SLE or other complement-mediated vasculopathy

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Thrombophilia workup in young patient with moyamoya and stroke
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Normal; deficiency → additional stroke risk factor

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Iron deficiency anemia can trigger TIA/stroke in moyamoya; maintain adequate iron stores
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Ferritin >50; iron deficiency → supplement before surgery

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: Normal; mutation → screen for systemic vascular involvement

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: NF1 is associated with moyamoya syndrome; café-au-lait spots, neurofibromas, optic glioma
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: No features; features present → NF1-associated moyamoya syndrome

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Trisomy 21 associated with moyamoya syndrome; higher prevalence than general population
If CNS vasculitis or infection in differential; atypical presentation

Essential/First-line.timing: Acute presentation: ischemic stroke vs hemorrhage; SAH screening; baseline
Rapid vascular assessment; bilateral ICA terminal/proximal MCA/ACA stenosis or occlusion; collateral network
Essential/First-line.target: **Classic**: Bilateral terminal ICA stenosis/occlusion with "puff of smoke" basal collaterals; evaluate Circle of Willis; external carotid collaterals

Essential/First-line.item: MRI brain with and without contrast (CPT 70553)
Essential/First-line.timing: Infarct characterization; ivy sign (leptomeningeal enhancement from slow flow); chronic changes; hemorrhage (GRE/SWI)
Essential/First-line.target: Infarcts (often watershed distribution); **"ivy sign"** on post-contrast FLAIR (leptomeningeal collateral enhancement); SWI: microbleeds (hemorrhagic risk); flow voids in basal ganglia (moyamoya vessels)

Essential/First-line.timing: Non-invasive vascular assessment; bilateral ICA stenosis; MCA/ACA flow reduction; collateral visualization
Essential/First-line.target: Bilateral terminal ICA stenosis/occlusion; diminished MCA/ACA flow; prominent moyamoya collaterals

Essential/First-line.timing: Cervical ICA assessment; extracranial disease; distinguish from atherosclerotic stenosis
Essential/First-line.target: Normal cervical ICAs (disease starts intracranially in true moyamoya); extracranial stenosis → atherosclerotic etiology

Extended.timing: **GOLD STANDARD for diagnosis and Suzuki staging**; defines vascular anatomy for surgical planning; evaluates collateral pathways; may reveal aneurysms on collaterals
Extended.target: Suzuki staging (I-VI); bilateral ICA terminal stenosis/occlusion; moyamoya collateral network; aneurysms on collaterals or posterior circulation; EC-IC collateral assessment
Extended.contraindications: Invasive (stroke risk 0.5-1% in moyamoya — INCREASED risk due to fragile collaterals); contrast allergy; renal insufficiency

Extended.timing: Acute hemodynamic assessment; identify penumbra; assess cerebrovascular reserve; helpful for surgical planning
Extended.target: Prolonged MTT/TTP; decreased CBF with maintained CBV (misery perfusion); stage I-II hemodynamic failure

Extended.timing: Non-invasive perfusion assessment; cerebrovascular reserve; serial monitoring without contrast (ASL); pre/post-surgical comparison
Extended.target: Decreased perfusion in ICA territory; asymmetric CBF; improved perfusion post-surgery

Extended.timing: Cerebrovascular reserve testing; assesses autoregulatory capacity; identifies "steal" phenomenon; helps determine surgical candidacy
Extended.target: Normal: >10% increase in CBF with acetazolamide; abnormal: failed augmentation or paradoxical decrease (steal) → surgery indicated
Extended.contraindications: Sulfonamide allergy; severe hepatic disease; prior acetazolamide reaction

Extended.timing: Non-invasive monitoring of MCA velocities; detect vasospasm; serial follow-up; screen for moyamoya in sickle cell
Extended.target: Elevated MCA velocities (stenosis); absent flow (occlusion); postoperative bypass patency monitoring

Extended.timing: "Re-buildup" phenomenon (slow recovery of background activity after hyperventilation is pathognomonic); seizure evaluation; baseline for surgery
Extended.target: **"Re-buildup" pattern**: slow waves persist >5 min after hyperventilation stops (reflects impaired cerebrovascular reserve); epileptiform activity if seizures
Extended.contraindications: None; **avoid prolonged hyperventilation during EEG in moyamoya** (can trigger ischemia)

Rare/Advanced.timing: Quantitative CBF measurement with acetazolamide challenge; research and specialized centers
Gold standard for cerebral hemodynamic assessment; OEF elevation indicates misery perfusion (stage II failure); strongest predictor of stroke risk
Rare/Advanced.target: Elevated OEF → stage II hemodynamic failure → surgical revascularization most beneficial

Rare/Advanced.timing: Non-invasive cerebrovascular reactivity mapping; emerging technique; CO2-BOLD CVR correlates with stroke risk
Rare/Advanced.target: Impaired CVR in ICA territories; asymmetry; guides surgical planning

Acute/Emergent.indication: **CRITICAL: Maintain euvolemia**; dehydration is major trigger for ischemic events in moyamoya; aggressive hydration during acute presentation

dosing.instructions: 125-250 mL/h isotonic crystalloid; maintain euvolemia; target urine output >0.5 mL/kg/h; AVOID hypovolemia (reduces perfusion through collaterals)

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Fluid balance; urine output; BMP q12h; avoid overhydration

Acute/Emergent.indication: Antiplatelet therapy for ischemic moyamoya; reduces thrombus formation in stenotic vessels and fragile collaterals

dosing.instructions: 81-325 mg PO daily; 81 mg preferred for long-term; 325 mg may be used acutely; continue indefinitely unless hemorrhagic presentation

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Active hemorrhage; hemorrhagic moyamoya presentation; allergy; severe bleeding risk
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Signs of bleeding; platelet function if concerns

Acute/Emergent.indication: **CRITICAL: Permissive hypertension in acute ischemic moyamoya**; collateral-dependent flow is pressure-sensitive; hypotension → watershed infarction

doseOptions.orderSentence: Blood pressure management — **AVOID HYPOTENSION** Target BP varies IV/PO

dosing.instructions: Acute ischemic: allow SBP up to 180-200 (unless hemorrhage or post-tPA); AVOID aggressive BP lowering; chronic: target ~10-20% above patient's baseline; NO specific BP target — individualize
dosing.orderSentence: Blood pressure management — **AVOID HYPOTENSION** Target BP varies IV/PO

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Avoid antihypertensives acutely unless SBP >220 or hemorrhagic; **DO NOT use IV nitroglycerin or nitroprusside (steal phenomenon)**
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Continuous BP monitoring; neuro checks q1h; avoid BP fluctuations

Acute/Emergent.item: Nicardipine (if BP too high with hemorrhage)
Acute/Emergent.indication: BP reduction ONLY if hemorrhagic presentation with SBP >180; or hypertensive emergency with end-organ damage

doseOptions.orderSentence: Nicardipine (if BP too high with hemorrhage) 5 mg/h titrated IV

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg/h; increase by 2.5 mg/h q5-15min; target SBP 140-160 for hemorrhagic moyamoya; AVOID dropping below 140
dosing.orderSentence: Nicardipine (if BP too high with hemorrhage) 5 mg/h titrated IV

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Arterial line preferred; avoid over-lowering; neuro checks q1h

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Headache (common in moyamoya due to collateral dilation); safe first-line analgesic; avoid NSAIDs (bleeding risk)

dosing.instructions: 650-1000 mg PO/IV q6h PRN; max 3000 mg/day; AVOID NSAIDs and aspirin combinations (GI bleed)

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Seizure treatment/prophylaxis; seizures occur in 20-30% of moyamoya patients; broad-spectrum; no hepatic metabolism

dosing.instructions: Start 500 mg BID; increase by 500 mg/day q1-2wk; max 3000 mg/day; IV loading 1000 mg over 15 min if needed

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Headache prevention in moyamoya (calcium channel blocker may improve collateral flow); migraine-like headache is common

dosing.instructions: Start 80 mg TID; increase by 80 mg q1wk; target 120 mg TID; max 480 mg/day; extended-release preferred

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Second/third-degree AV block; severe LV dysfunction; concurrent beta-blocker
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: HR; BP; ECG; constipation; avoid in hypotension

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Iron deficiency anemia correction; anemia worsens cerebral ischemia in moyamoya; optimize before surgery

doseOptions.orderSentence: Iron supplementation (if deficient) 325 mg ferrous sulfate daily PO

dosing.instructions: 325 mg (65 mg elemental iron) PO daily on empty stomach; may increase to BID if tolerated; target ferritin >50
dosing.orderSentence: Iron supplementation (if deficient) 325 mg ferrous sulfate daily PO

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Ferritin, iron studies q3 months until replete

Medical Management (Long-term).indication: Long-term antiplatelet therapy for all moyamoya patients with ischemic presentation; reduces ischemic events; continue post-surgery

dosing.instructions: 81 mg PO daily indefinitely; hold 7 days before surgery then resume 24-48h post-op per neurosurgical guidance

Medical Management (Long-term).contraindications: Active hemorrhage; hemorrhagic moyamoya without ischemic history; allergy

Medical Management (Long-term).indication: Vascular risk factor optimization; pleiotropic effects (endothelial function, anti-inflammatory); may benefit even with non-atherosclerotic disease

dosing.instructions: Start 20-40 mg daily; target LDL <70 given high vascular risk; monitor LFTs

Medical Management (Long-term).monitoring: LFTs at baseline and 3 months; CK if myalgia; lipid panel q6 months

Medical Management (Long-term).indication: Antiplatelet with vasodilatory properties; may improve collateral development; studied in moyamoya as adjunct to aspirin

dosing.instructions: Start 50 mg BID; increase to 100 mg BID if tolerated; take 30 min before or 2h after meals

Medical Management (Long-term).monitoring: Headache (common, usually transient); HR; bleeding signs

Surgical Revascularization.indication: **Most effective surgical option**: Direct anastomosis of superficial temporal artery to middle cerebral artery branch; immediate flow augmentation; preferred in adults

doseOptions.orderSentence: STA-MCA bypass (direct revascularization) N/A — surgical procedure Surgical

dosing.instructions: Microsurgical anastomosis; STA donor to M4 cortical MCA branch; provides immediate blood flow augmentation; most evidence in adults
dosing.orderSentence: STA-MCA bypass (direct revascularization) N/A — surgical procedure Surgical

Surgical Revascularization.pretreatment: Complete presurgical workup: DSA, perfusion imaging, neuropsych; optimize Hgb >10; hold aspirin per surgeon; adequate STA caliber on CTA/ultrasound
Surgical Revascularization.contraindications: Inadequate donor (STA) or recipient vessels; active infection; severe medical comorbidities precluding craniotomy; recent large infarct (<6 weeks)
Surgical Revascularization.monitoring: Post-op: ICU 24-48h; BP strictly controlled (avoid hypo- and hypertension); TCD daily; CT if deficit; hydration; avoid hyperventilation; aspirin resume 24-48h

Surgical Revascularization.indication: Indirect revascularization; STA laid on brain surface to promote neoangiogenesis over weeks-months; combined with direct bypass in adults; primary technique in pediatrics

doseOptions.orderSentence: EDAS (encephaloduroarteriosynangiosis — indirect) N/A — surgical procedure Surgical

dosing.instructions: Dissected STA branch sutured to dural edges overlying cortex; new collateral formation occurs over 3-6 months; may be combined with direct bypass (combined approach)
dosing.orderSentence: EDAS (encephaloduroarteriosynangiosis — indirect) N/A — surgical procedure Surgical

Surgical Revascularization.contraindications: Same as direct bypass; less technically demanding; longer time to full benefit
Surgical Revascularization.monitoring: Same as direct bypass; follow-up angiography at 6-12 months to assess new collateral formation

Surgical Revascularization.indication: Indirect revascularization using temporalis muscle; often combined with EDAS or direct bypass; additional blood supply source

doseOptions.orderSentence: EMS (encephalomyosynangiosis — indirect) N/A — surgical procedure Surgical

dosing.instructions: Temporalis muscle dissected and laid on cortical surface; promotes collateral growth; less effective alone than EDAS or direct bypass
dosing.orderSentence: EMS (encephalomyosynangiosis — indirect) N/A — surgical procedure Surgical

Surgical Revascularization.indication: **Preferred approach in adults**: Direct bypass (immediate flow) + indirect (EDAS/EMS for additional long-term collateral development); maximizes revascularization

doseOptions.orderSentence: Combined direct + indirect revascularization N/A — combined procedure Surgical

dosing.instructions: STA-MCA bypass + EDAS or EMS in same operative session; provides immediate + delayed revascularization; bilateral surgery staged 1-3 months apart
dosing.orderSentence: Combined direct + indirect revascularization N/A — combined procedure Surgical

Surgical Revascularization.pretreatment: Complete presurgical evaluation; bilateral procedures staged (contralateral side 1-3 months later after recovery)
Surgical Revascularization.contraindications: Same as individual procedures; hemodynamic instability
Surgical Revascularization.monitoring: ICU post-op; staged bilateral procedures; repeat perfusion imaging between stages

Surgical Revascularization.indication: Alternative indirect technique when STA inadequate or in regions not covered by standard bypass; promotes neoangiogenesis through dural openings

doseOptions.orderSentence: Multiple burr holes (indirect) N/A — surgical procedure Surgical

dosing.instructions: Multiple burr holes placed over ischemic territory; dura opened at each site; promotes collateral ingrowth; less invasive; may supplement other techniques
dosing.orderSentence: Multiple burr holes (indirect) N/A — surgical procedure Surgical

Surgical Revascularization.pretreatment: Less effective than direct bypass; used when other options limited

Referrals & Consults.item: Cerebrovascular neurosurgery consultation with moyamoya expertise for all patients; early surgical referral improves outcomes
Neurology consultation for acute stroke management, medical optimization, and long-term monitoring
Neuropsychological testing baseline before surgery and at 6-12 months post-surgery to assess cognitive outcomes
Anesthesiology pre-operative consultation with emphasis on: AVOID hyperventilation (reduces PaCO2 → vasoconstriction → ischemia); maintain normotension; avoid dehydration; ketamine caution
Hematology referral if sickle cell disease, thrombophilia, or polycythemia contributing to moyamoya syndrome
Genetics counseling if bilateral moyamoya disease (familial screening recommended; RNF213 in East Asian populations; ACTA2 for systemic vascular moyamoya)
Physical therapy for stroke rehabilitation; occupational therapy for ADL adaptation; speech therapy if aphasia
Ophthalmology referral for retinal vascular assessment (moyamoya can affect retinal vessels)

Patient Instructions.item: **STAY WELL HYDRATED at all times**; dehydration is the most dangerous trigger for ischemic events in moyamoya — drink at least 2-3 liters of fluid daily; increase during illness, exercise, or hot weather
Return to ED immediately if new weakness, numbness, vision changes, speech difficulty, severe headache, or any new neurologic symptom — do not wait to see if it improves

**AVOID hyperventilation**: Do not blow up balloons, play wind instruments, blow-dry hair on hot settings prolonged, or perform breathing exercises that involve forced deep breathing — hyperventilation causes cerebral vasoconstriction and can trigger stroke
Avoid excessive crying in children; teach older patients to avoid Valsalva maneuvers (heavy straining, breath-holding) as these can reduce cerebral perfusion
Take aspirin daily as prescribed; do not stop without consulting neurologist; carry a medication list at all times
Avoid extreme temperature exposure (hot baths, saunas, cold exposure) which can trigger hemodynamic changes and ischemic events

Inform all physicians and dentists about moyamoya diagnosis before any procedure; anesthesia requires special precautions; avoid vasoconstrictive medications (triptans, ergotamines, decongestants with pseudoephedrine)
Wear medical alert identification indicating moyamoya disease and "avoid hyperventilation"

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Maintain adequate hydration (2-3 L/day minimum); carry water bottle; increase fluids during illness or physical activity
Regular low-to-moderate intensity exercise encouraged for cardiovascular health; avoid competitive or extreme sports; avoid activities with significant dehydration risk
Iron-rich diet or supplementation to maintain adequate hemoglobin; anemia worsens ischemic symptoms
Avoid smoking and secondhand smoke (vascular damage; reduces oxygen-carrying capacity)
Blood pressure management: avoid both hypertension AND hypotension; individualized BP targets; home BP monitoring twice daily
Family screening with MRA recommended for first-degree relatives, especially in East Asian populations with bilateral disease (10-15% familial)

differential.features: Older age; vascular risk factors (DM, HTN, smoking); unilateral preferred; no moyamoya collaterals; extracranial disease common
differential.tests: DSA (focal plaque vs progressive stenosis); CTA (calcification); risk factor profile; MRI (embolic pattern not watershed)

differential.features: Multifocal irregular narrowing of multiple vessel sizes; CSF pleocytosis/elevated protein; may respond to immunosuppression
differential.tests: CSF analysis (inflammatory); brain biopsy (gold standard); DSA (beading pattern); ESR/CRP; MRI (multifocal lesions)

differential.features: History of cranial radiation (typically childhood); progressive stenosis years after treatment; unilateral more common
differential.tests: Radiation history; MRI (radiation changes); progressive stenosis in radiation field

differential.features: Typically cervical/renal arteries; "string of beads" on angiography; not typically intracranial
differential.tests: CTA/MRA ("string of beads" in cervical ICA/renal arteries); spares intracranial vessels typically

differential.features: Known sickle cell disease; progressive ICA stenosis similar to moyamoya; moyamoya syndrome
differential.tests: Hemoglobin electrophoresis; sickle cell confirmed; management differs (chronic transfusion)

differential.features: Café-au-lait spots; neurofibromas; optic glioma; progressive intracranial stenosis
differential.tests: Clinical features of NF1; genetic testing; imaging of moyamoya pattern + NF1 features

differential.features: Trisomy 21; moyamoya pattern; may present with stroke in young patient
differential.tests: Karyotype; clinical features; imaging shows moyamoya pattern

differential.features: Large vessel vasculitis; aorta and branches; may involve carotid → intracranial; systemic symptoms; elevated ESR
differential.tests: ESR/CRP markedly elevated; aortic arch imaging; systemic symptoms; younger women

differential.features: Recurrent thrombosis; pregnancy loss; livedo reticularis; progressive vascular occlusion can mimic moyamoya
differential.tests: aPL antibodies (lupus anticoagulant, anticardiolipin, anti-β2GP1); coagulation studies

RNF213 as susceptibility gene for moyamoya disease
Suzuki staging system for moyamoya angiographic progression
Direct bypass superior to indirect in adults; combined approach recommended
Hemorrhagic moyamoya management: surgical revascularization reduces rebleeding
Hyperventilation avoidance critical in moyamoya (cerebrovascular reactivity impaired)
Dehydration is major stroke trigger in moyamoya; hydration maintenance essential
Cerebrovascular reserve testing (acetazolamide SPECT/PET) predicts surgical benefit
Family screening recommended for first-degree relatives; 10-15% familial incidence

monitoring.frequency: q1h acute; q4h stable inpatient; BID at home
monitoring.action: Hypotension → fluid bolus, reduce antihypertensives; hypertension → cautious treatment (avoid over-lowering)

monitoring.frequency: q1h acute; q4h stable; each clinic visit
monitoring.action: New deficit → STAT imaging; OR evaluation if post-operative
Dehydrated → aggressive IV/PO hydration; urine output low → bolus

monitoring.frequency: Admission; q6-12h post-op; q3-6 months outpatient
monitoring.action: Anemia → transfuse if <7 or symptomatic; iron supplementation
Progressive stenosis → repeat perfusion; surgical revision consideration
Worsening perfusion → re-evaluate for additional revascularization

monitoring.frequency: Post-op daily x 3 days; q6 months outpatient
monitoring.action: Increasing velocities → progressive stenosis; absent flow → occlusion; asymmetric → surgical hemisphere assessment
Re-buildup present → impaired reserve → consider surgical referral

disposition.criteria: Acute stroke (ischemic or hemorrhagic); post-surgical revascularization (24-48h); refractory hypo/hypertension; seizures; large infarct with edema
TIA with new diagnosis; workup and surgical planning; stable post-ICU; medical optimization before surgery

Stable neurologic exam; adequate PO hydration demonstrated; BP at target; antiplatelet therapy started; follow-up arranged with cerebrovascular neurosurgery and neurology; patient/family educated on hydration and hyperventilation avoidance
Diagnosis confirmed but facility lacks cerebrovascular neurosurgery expertise for bypass surgery; complex bilateral disease
Neurology q3-6 months; neurosurgery per surgical timeline; MRA annually; perfusion imaging per protocol
